The investigators form a "Mathematics and Climate Research
Network." This is a framework for an intensive effort aimed at
bringing to bear the full power of modern applied mathematics and
statistics on the prediction and understanding of the Earth's
climate. The investigators focus on three key themes: (1)
Dynamics of Climate, (2) Climate Process Modeling, and (3) Data
Analysis and Data Assimilation. Dynamics of Climate addresses
critical climate processes and their interactions. Climate
Process Modeling undertakes the modeling of climate components
that have been underrepresented in extant climate models, such as
the multi-scale material structure of sea ice. Data Analysis and
Data Assimilation develops mathematical tools for analyzing
climate data and assimilating them in current climate models.
The Research Network aims to be a national resource, with
participants at thirteen U.S. universities. The investigators
work together as a virtual community that holds regular weekly
"webinars" and working meetings over the Internet. This
multi-year effort is expected to help in defining a research area
of "climate mathematics" and in educating a new generation of
mathematical researchers to meet the scientific challenges
associated with a changing climate.

This project is driven by the need to better understand the
Earth's climate system. Climate is the result of many
geophysical and chemical processes in the Earth's atmosphere,
oceans and biosphere. These processes evolve in time over many
scales, ranging from minutes to centuries, and interact in
multiple ways, most often nonlinearly. Feedback mechanisms, many
of which are poorly understood, further complicate the picture.
Because there is only one Earth, climate cannot be studied by
systematic experimentation; the only approach available to
climate researchers is through computational experiments. These
experiments are based on mathematical models, which must be
simple enough not to exceed the capabilities of today's advanced
computer architectures, while still incorporating the physical
and chemical processes that are essential for realistic climate
outcomes. The expertise of mathematical scientists in designing,
assessing and interpreting these models is critical. This
"Mathematics and Climate Research Network" helps engage the
mathematical sciences community to address the mathematical and
statistical issues of our changing climate. The Research Network
takes full advantage of current information technology;
communication and collaboration among the participants takes
place mostly remotely over the Internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Realistic models of Earth’s climate system are crucial to making projections about what humans may experience as our climate changes. The climate system – the oceans, atmosphere, land, ice, and biosphere, and their interactions – is governed by the laws and equations of physics, chemistry, and fluid motion. Models of climate that can be solved on powerful computers are mathematical in nature, as are many issues and questions connected with our changing climate. The overarching goal of the Mathematics and Climate Research Network (MCRN) is to help build an area of climate mathematics, aimed at bringing to bear the full power of modern applied mathematics and statistics on the prediction and understanding of Earth's climate. We immersed a large cadre of young mathematicians, from high school students and undergraduates to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, in important problems of climate science with a mathematical dimension. In this way, we are bringing a new level of rigor and mathematical objectivity to addressing the most challenging problems in understanding and modeling the climate system. To this end, we established 12 hubs at major universities across the US which served as centers for mathematical research and education in climate, and a sophisticated online hub hosting a virtual climate math community in the US and abroad to conduct research, attend webinars, and provide educational resources.

At the University of Utah we have focused on mathematical problems involving Earth’s sea ice packs and their role in the climate system. In particular, we are developing models from the mathematics of composite materials and statistical physics to study sea ice structures and processes. Our mathematical work is developed in conjunction with field measurements of related sea ice properties in the Arctic and Antarctic. We have made fundamental advances in explaining the evolution of melt ponds on Arctic sea ice and in modeling fluid flow through the porous brine microstructure of sea ice. Such processes must be accounted for in climate models so that they can capture the precipitous losses of sea ice observed in the Arctic. Due to the close similarity of sea ice microstructure to the porous microstructure of human bone, we applied techniques for analyzing the connectivity of the brine phase in sea ice to monitoring the progress of osteoporosis in humans, and we have applied ideas from medical imaging to sea ice remote sensing. We have involved mathematics undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs in both Arctic and Antarctic expeditions, to have a much deeper understanding of, and direct experience with, the systems they are modeling. Our research at the University of Utah in integrating rigorous mathematics with field observations is being used to improve projections of the fate of Earth’s sea ice packs and the response of polar ecosystems they support.
